/* Characteristics */ Simon Frith, cited by Weinstein
/* Characteristics */ Weinstein says keyboards are "integral to the sound" of HM
Weinstein also says HM is a genre of rock
/* New fusions: 1990s and early 2000s */ see below
/* Underground metal: 1980s, 1990s, and 2000s */ consistent style for sample titles
Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/59.101.205.160|59.101.205.160]] ([[User talk:59.101.205.160|talk]]) to last version by DCGeist
/* Classical influence */ remove section on consecutive fifths..this is appears to be Original Research. Yes, there are sources from various Classical encyclopedias, but none mention HM
/* Characteristics */ more drumming info from "Drummers Bible"
/* Characteristics */ more Weinstein.. .her theories on WHY metal bands love loudness
/* Characteristics */ add "sensory equivalent of war" quote from Arnett's book "Metalheads", trim some Spinal Tap details, trim Blue Cheer quote to the essential
/* Rhythm and groove */ retitle..."groove" is more of a funk term than a metal term...have added stuff on tempos from Weinstein and from Berry/Gianni's "Drummer's Bible"
/* Death metal */ replace incorrectly cited photo with more relevant image
/* Lyrical themes */ - added a snippet about the Judas Priest case
/* Physical gestures */ add in more sourced stuff from Umelec
/* Physical gestures */ add more Umelec content
/* Visual elements */ Covach says Motorhead helped add biker culture and leather clothes to metal scene
/* Visual elements */ metal fashion history...sourced from Umelec, a Czech-English art and culture mag
source on long hair's association with metal

/* Visual elements */ put in long hair...obvious, but imagine a person new to subject (perhaps living as hermit for last 30 years)...add copyedits, and point out that music videos are part of the imag

Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/70.107.123.178|70.107.123.178]] identified as [[WP:VAND|vandalism]] to last revision by [[User:DCGeist|DCGeist]]. using [[WP:TW|TW]]
/* New fusions: 1990s and early 2000s */ sorry, gotta cut this quote--appears to come from press release for book, not book itself
/* History */ remove tag--all images vetted and violations corrected
/* New fusions*/ce: cut part of Covach quote--not place to detail grunge and very debatable on "major label" point; differentate nu metal sentence a bit more from descrip in "Characteristics"
/* Mainstream: late 1970s and 1980s */ ce--move info for better chrono; retain cite, no need to name critic in main text for this basic observation
/* Mainstream: late 1970s and 1980s */ better placement, leaves last sent as transitoin
/* Mainstream: late 1970s and 1980s */ gloss shred, for those who aren't familiar with the style
/* Mainstream: late 1970s and 1980s */ oopss... Warrant mentioned at opening of para..must reword
/* Mainstream: late 1970s and 1980s */these three bands are listed as "three other notable late 80s bands" in the Norton history of Rock...this not just an editor's POV! : )
/* New fusions: 1990s and early 2000s */add point that some nu met bands had DJ scratching, ambient noises
/* New fusions: 1990s and early 2000s */ add para break, remove informal "thanks"
/* New fusions: 1990s and early 2000s */ add Norton History of ROck quotes on Grung
/* Characteristics */ add quote from BLogcritics Magazine
/* Characteristics */ ce cymbal choke sentence to general descrip; cut quote & cite--we really can't add a blog cite to a featured article (and we should double-check that there aren't any others)
rv tag; evidenced and sourced in main text; [[WP:UNDO|Undid]] revision 171941626 by [[Special:Contributions/WyomingSlim|WyomingSlim]] ([[User talk:WyomingSlim|talk]])
/* New fusions: 1990s and early 2000s */ add quote on how metal has become mainstream (Osbournes show)...source is Rough Guide to Heav Met
Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/203.37.99.146|203.37.99.146]]; Rv blanking. using [[WP:TW|TW]]
/* Characteristics */ Omigod...how could we have collectively overlooked that great metal drum technique, the CYMBAL CHOKE...yes the source is a blog, but I think the choke is a well-known sound
/* Black metal */ add lo-fi to Black Metal, with cite

put longer quote... Sorry Dan and other editors, about the mistake...the source talks about Death Metal and Black Metal together right up to that point, then it splits off to only deal with Black Metl
/* Black metal */ li'l ce for clarity
/* Black metal */ ce per elim of preceding quote that refers specifically to black metal, not death
/* Death metal */ cut quote that refers specifically to black metal bands
/* Death metal */ add quote on experimentation
/* Recent trends: mid-2000s */ add verifiable data that also signals ongoing ambiguity between definitions of "hard rock" and "metal"
/* Black metal */ change what sounded like weasel wording into a more credible sentence ...from the weasel word fave "some" to the source
/* Black metal */ add quote from Netherlands metal mag...notes that Black metal incorporates other musical influences...plus rejigged paragraphing
/* Death metal */ add details, with ref from Magazine: Slagwerkkrant / Netherlands
restore quote--point is not to disparage the elder Plant at all, but to demonstrate the comparison and historical link
/* Recent trends: mid-2000s */ "notes that Plant can't hit anymore"...not a useful point to include...singers lose range with age, so it is not a big achievement for a younger singer
/* Recent trends: mid-2000s */ remove unsourced claims that Wolfmother's debut album "sold well" and was "widely praised by critics" (this could be weasel wording)
/* Characteristics */ attempt to reword rhythmic cell sentence...retain every word except "dynamic", because there are too many adjectives
/* Characteristics */ 1977 reviewer noted how excessive volume was part of Motorhead sound
/* Harmony */ add melbay guitar glossary reference...states that power chord is a fifth + octave...doesn't mention thirds, dim 5ths, etc
/* Harmony */ clarifying point, per FD's discussion in Talk
/* Alternative and nu metal: 1990s and early 2000s */ broader section title--in keeping with others
/* Characteristics */ ce--we need to have SOMETHING explaining how power chords are compatible with distortion...I've restored the serviceable, long-standing phrase
no subheds necessary for the general history sections--"glam metal" doesn't adequately cover relevant passage anyway
/* Rhythm and groove */ trim "in other words", and remove wording about "rough" patterns
/* Harmony */reword power chord section... "saturation" is a Peavey trademark for distortion, and the term is used informally, but I don't think its a proper audio engineering term
/* Mainstream: late 1970s and 1980s */ this long section needs some subheadings...add Glam Metal subheading
/* Classical influence */ Baroque era is often deemed to end with J.S. Bach's death in 1750...by 1800, we're getting into Beethoven, more Classical stuff
/* Alternative and nu metal: 1990s and early 2000s */ substitute more significant song and band
/* Doom and gothic metal */ ce caption for clarity
/* History */ move sound sample to appropriate spot
Sorry - I didn't see the rationale on the image page. Thanks for adding it :)
There is no fair use rationale for the image to appear in this article. If you want it to appear here, you must justify it on the image description page. See [[WP:NFC]] for details
/* Black metal */ impt image restored--specific fair use rationale applied
/* History */ This section contains too much non-free media
rm image with no fair use rationale for this page
important image restored--specific rationale added on image page
rm image with no fair use rationale for this page
Unproper. Dissonance is a specific term applied to intervals not to distortion. Besides a Interval such as Diminished fifth IS classified as a dissonance so there is dissonance anyway in this case.
/* Harmony and chording */ Pleonasm...Harmony science includes chording
/* Classical influence */ These musicians are more interested by late (1800s) baroque (Bach, Vivaldi, Albinoni,etc..) than 1700s Early baroque
/* Harmony and chording */ try it without subheadings...look at a mainstream commercial music encyclopedia like Rolling Stone...very few subheadings
/* Musical language */ reduce number of subheadings...I think
/* Chords */ edit.... minor 6th powerchords aren't common
/* Rhythm and groove */ reword some hard-to-understand prose...I think this is what the editor meant, in plainer English
/* Visual elements */ separate physical gestures into 2 categories...gestures bands make, and gestures that audiences do
/* Physical gestures */ combine phys gest with visual elements
/* Characteristics */ add NY Times quote about Metal
/* Lyrical themes */ add NY Times reference to Heavy Metal lyrics section
/* Characteristics */ refer to the huge drum kits in metal...with reference (try finding one...it is hard)
/* Characteristics */ add Modern Drummer summary of metal drumming: "speed, power, and precision"
/* Characteristics */ ce for clarity and concision
rvv--repeat spammer of link to cherished deletable article with nonsensical title

rv--"sociopolitical' is closed per Webster's, American Heritage, Chicago Manual of Style, etc.
/* Origins: late 1960s and early 1970s */ GFR debut

ce 3d graf of lede for better chrono, elim redundancy
No mistake: It was absolutely not said that power chord cause distortion(of course they don't ). It is said that power chords make possible the USE of high distortion without dissonance.
/* Mainstream: late 1970s and 1980s */ ce more defensible--dubious about "alcohol and drugs"
/* Mainstream: late 1970s and 1980s */ more distinguishing attribute
/* Characteristics */ neither the hammond nor the mellotron were acoustic
/* Typical harmonic relationships */ ce and tighten long note
/* Recent trends: mid-2000s */ merge unique stacked cites
/* The alternative era and nu metal: 1990s and 2000s */
/* Mainstream: late 1970s and 1980s */ sentence just on Bon Jovi for better history
/* Mainstream: late 1970s and 1980s */ correct link, li'l ce
/* Themes */ put glam visual detail here--helps stubby graf
ce; restore better chrono to history, integrating some of new material (remember, we do have a whole article on glam); elim some redundant wikilinks
/* Origins: late 1960s and early 1970s */ refine point
/* Chords */ fix mistake....power chords don't cause distortion....power chords CAN be used with heavy distortion, unlike a jazz type D 7 (add 9, sharp 11) chord, which sounds like hell with dstrn
/* Thrash metal */ add lede from thrash article, as it nicely sums up the genre
/* Mainstream: late 1970s and 1980s */ add more glam metal content...although we might not like to admit it, men with spandex and lipstick and big hair were a big thing in the 80s....
/* Origin of the term heavy metal */ edt
/* Themes */ Judas Priest sued for suicide attempts
rv--"romantic tragedy" adds little, 'socio-political commentary" is clearly redundant of material further down in graf
